lines.text: Why didn't you shoot, Curtis?
Same reason I wouldn't let your uncle kill the dog. You might be useful on this trip.
We might as well get this straight right now. You give all the orders you want, but not to me. I don't work for you.
You've been hired...
I was hired, but not by you! The minute I take over responsibility for this wagon train, I'm working for every man, woman and child in it. I'll see that you get where you're going. That's my job.
How much?
It's about $25 a wagon.
Twenty-five... Oh, I don't know. That's a lot of money.
Wagon bosses don't work cheap.
Ah, is this horse worth that to ya?
Does the saddle come with the deal?
It's a little warm for Christmas, ain't it, Mister?
We're very grateful to you for what you did.

[referring to the beating he just gave to Ann's boyfriend, Clay]
Oh, I guess somebody would have had to do it to him sooner or later.

[rubbing his jaw]
It wasn't all one-sided.
I meant we're grateful for bringing Ben home!
Oh. Well, that was a pleasure, too.
Did you make this?
I did. As good as pheasant, Mr. Curtis?
Better.

[to his dog]
Come on, Buzz. Some roughneck.
[last lines]

[as Jeff takes Ann into his arms]
Some roughneck.

The courage and strength of the men and women who settled the United States in the westward movement of the Nineteenth Century has become an honored and legendary part of our history. The pioneering spirit of these people, remarkable as it was could not have proved so effective without direction and guidance. A handful of men, known as wagonmasters, made it their business to guide pioneer families westward across the mountains and the plains. Whatever their motive might have been in choosing such careers, the fact remains that without them our colonization of the West would have taken a lot longer than it did. This is the story of one such wagonmaster - Jeff Curtis.
Why didn't you let Jeff slug him, Marshal? He had it comin'.
Whatever he has coming will catch up to him. It always does, son.

[referring to Jeff]
He's quite a man.
From what I hear he's a irresponsible roughneck!
Irresponsible? I wouldn't say that. But in ths part of the country, it helps to be a roughneck.
Wagons west!
